journal-meta.journal-title: World Journal for Pediatric and Congenital Heart Surgery

subj-group.subject: Proceedings of the WSPCHS Symposium on the Functionally Univentricular Heart

title-group.article-title: Intensive Care and Perioperative Management of Neonates With Functionally Univentricular Hearts

article-meta.aff: 1The Heart Institute, Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, University of Cincinnati School of Medicine, Cincinnati, OH, USA

2The Congenital Heart Institute of Florida (CHIF), Division of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery, All Children’s Hospital/Children’s Hospital of Tampa, University of South Florida College of Medicine, Cardiac Surgical Associates, Saint Petersburg and Tampa, FL, USA

author-notes.corresp: David S. Cooper, The Heart Institute Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, University of Cincinnati, 3333 Burnet Avenue, MLC 2003, Cincinnati, OH 45229, USA Email: David.Cooper@cchmc.org

permissions.copyright-holder: World Society for Pediatric and Congential Heart Surgery

abstract.p: Although mortality rates for patients with univentricular hearts continue to fall, the course in the intensive care unit is remarkable for significant morbidity and utilization of significant resources. Preoperative patient management focuses on balancing competing circulations, pulmonary and systemic, which exist in parallel rather than in series, as in the normal circulation. Postoperative patient management focuses on optimizing systemic output, respiratory status, and mitigating the effects of cardiopulmonary bypass. In this article, we review pre- and postoperative intensive care management in neonates with a univentricular heart.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Univentricular or functionally univentricular hearts may result from a variety of anatomic lesions. Regardless of the etiology, newborns with these lesions have mixing of the systemic and pulmonary venous return. Preoperative patient management focuses on balancing competing circulations, pulmonary and systemic, which exist in parallel rather than in series, as in the normal circulation. The infant with a truly “balanced” circulation is relatively rare, thus most patients will require surgical intervention to provide unobstructed systemic (Qs) blood flow and restrictive pulmonary (Qp) blood flow. Postoperative patient management focuses on optimizing systemic output, respiratory status, and mitigating the effects of cardiopulmonary bypass. In this article, we review pre- and postoperative intensive care management in neonates with a univentricular heart. Accordingly, we have limited our discussion of postoperative care to neonates who have undergone Norwood palliation. Management of patients who have undergone hybrid surgical and catheter palliation is beyond the scope of this review.

sec.title: Initial Diagnosis and Presentation
sec.p: Neonates with undiagnosed single ventricle anatomy present with symptoms ranging from cyanosis to shock based on the underlying anatomy and relative distribution of pulmonary and systemic blood flows. Fortunately, advances in fetal echocardiography have made the number of infants who present in extremis increasingly rare. Recent studies have reported rates of prenatal diagnosis of complex congenital heart disease (CHD) approaching 75%, with higher rates in more severe disease.1,2 Retrospective studies comparing infants with and without prenatally diagnosed CHD have shown prenatal diagnosis is associated with lower lactate, higher pH,3,4and lower incidence of tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular dysfunction.3 Levey and colleagues2 have also shown prenatal diagnosis is associated with decreased antibiotic and ventilator use as well as lower rates of emergent surgery. Early reports also suggest prenatal diagnosis improved patient mortality3; however, follow-up studies have failed to show a similar mortality benefit but intonate a potential benefit with regard to morbidity.1,2,5

An unanticipated consequence of prenatal diagnosis among infants with CHD has been the trend toward early, elective delivery in an attempt to assure delivery at tertiary care facilities and minimize the risk of late fetal demise. This practice was called into question based on studies showing increased adverse outcomes among “healthy” infants delivered before 39 weeks of gestation.6 Likewise, studies in patients with critical CHD have shown incremental declines in hospital mortality and morbidity as gestational age approached 40 weeks7,8, further supporting the avoidance of elective preterm delivery. However, recently Atz and colleagues demonstrated that patients who are diagnosed prenatally compared to postnatally continue to be delivered prematurely.1

sec.title: Preoperative Hemodynamic Management
sec.p: Following admission to the cardiac intensive care unit (ICU), the care team must first investigate the perinatal events and delineate anatomic/physiologic details of the cardiac defect. This information will be used to determine the timing of surgery. In the interim, management of an unpalliated univentricular heart focuses on maintaining adequate, but not excessive pulmonary blood flow, while providing adequate systemic blood flow to meet the body’s metabolic demands. Traditionally, adequacy of support was assessed using oxygen saturation as an indirect measure of Qp:Qs; however, unrecognized pulmonary venous desaturation may confuse the matter, particularly in the postoperative patient.9 In recent years, the care paradigm has shifted from monitoring for pulmonary overcirculation to monitoring systemic Qs and oxygen delivery. It is understood that the single ventricle is pumping Qp plus Qs and that the distribution of the total output from the single ventricle will determine whether there is adequate Qs and oxygen delivery given that most neonates with univentricular physiology have a Qp:Qs that is greater than 1:1. More recently, direct assessment of oxygen delivery using near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) to assess regional tissue oxygen saturation has become increasingly common. The NIRS has been shown to correlate with superior vena cava (SVC) saturation among pediatric cardiac surgery patients.10 Furthermore, two-site, cerebral and flank, NIRS both individually11 and averaged12 have been shown to be an effective means to assess for hypoperfusion among infants with CHD. Two-site NIRS has also been shown to facilitate the preoperative management of patients with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). Johnson and colleagues demonstrated that management with NIRS resulted in decreased preoperative controlled ventilation, reduced mean ventilation time and inspired gas use, and decreased ventilation costs.11

sec.title: Preoperative Ventilator Management
sec.p: Stabilization of the patient with excessive pulmonary blood flow contributing to inadequate systemic blood flow and oxygen delivery prior to surgery can be challenging. Previously, mechanical ventilation has been employed in preoperative patients with excessive tachypnea and high oxygen saturation (SaO 2). Currently, it is felt that invasive respiratory support of the preoperative patient should be reserved for those with respiratory insufficiency/failure or low systemic output. A number of strategies including inspired carbon dioxide (ventilated patient), hypoxia (via increasing inspired nitrogen), and generous positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) 13 have been employed to increase pulmonary vascular resistance and reduce pulmonary blood flow. Increasing inspired carbon dioxide and reducing alveolar oxygen (via increasing inspired nitrogen) have both been employed to decrease pulmonary blood flow. While both hypoxia and hypercarbia have been shown to decrease Qp:Qs,14,15 hypoxia should be used with caution due to concerns about its ability to cause pulmonary venous desaturation. Furthermore, while Tabbutt and colleagues15 showed both hypoxia (N2) and hypercarbia decreased Qp:Qs, only hypercarbia increased cardiac output (as assessed by AVO2 difference and mixed venous oxygen saturation). Ultimately, if a patient is unable to be stabilized effectively via medical management, there should be no delay in achieving a more favorable anatomic and physiologic state via surgical intervention with placement of an aorto-pulmonary artery shunt that will restrict pulmonary blood flow allowing more of the univentricular output to the systemic circulation.

sec.title: Postoperative Goal-Directed Therapy
sec.p: Care of an infant following the Norwood procedure remains focused on maintaining adequate oxygen delivery to meet the metabolic demands of the body. Noncardiovascular manipulations to optimize oxygen delivery (DO2) and minimize oxygen consumption (VO2) are often employed including, sedation, neuromuscular blockade (if absolutely necessary) and maintenance of normothermia or mild hypothermia. Avoidance of arrhythmias is also important. With regard to hemodynamic monitoring, both SVC saturation as a surrogate of mixed venous saturation and NIRS are becoming mainstays of postoperative care.16–18 In addition to the considerations mentioned above, postoperative management must also account for the detrimental effects of cardiopulmonary bypass resulting in alterations of pulmonary and systemic vasculature resistance and myocardial dysfunction. Low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS) following CPB is common and of significant concern.19 Depressed myocardial function following CPB is commonly treated with vasoactive infusion support. When selecting an inotrope to achieve the goal of increased contractility, one must not only consider its impact on oxygen delivery but on consumption as well. Li and colleagues20 demonstrated that while following the Norwood procedure dopamine results in increased heart rate, it also increases oxygen consumption and the extraction ratio of oxygen resulting in no net increase in cardiac output or DO2. Many have advocated the use of mixed venous saturation as a measure of systemic oxygen delivery. Tweddell and colleagues have shown that mixed venous saturation during the first 48 hours following Norwood procedure correlates with the risk of postoperative complications, including cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).17 This may be a particularly valuable surveillance tool, given the incidence of CPR and ECMO reported in the recent Pediatric Heart Network Single Ventricle Reconstruction trial.21 Following modified Blalock-Taussig shunt (BTS) placement, pulmonary overcirculation, at the expense of systemic blood flow, remains a concern and is commonly treated by increasing total cardiac output and modulating systemic afterload. Decreased ventricular function, significant atrioventricular valve regurgitation, or loss of atrio-ventricular synchrony may result in inadequate Qs and oxygen delivery even though the Qp:Qs ratio is not very high. Recent studies have shown improved oxygen delivery correlates closely with a reduction in postoperative SVR among neonates who have undergone the Norwood procedure with modified BTS22 or right ventricle to pulmonary artery (RV-PA) conduit.23 Neither study was able to show a significant correlation between PVR and oxygen delivery and confirms the current focus of postoperative therapy on minimizing oxygen consumption and SVR. Additionally, a number of studies have shown NIRS to be a valuable tool in our armamentarium to identify LCOS after Norwood palliation. Two-site NIRS has been shown to correlate with cardiogenic shock and anaerobic metabolism.24

sec.title: Transfusion
sec.p: Among nonpharmacologic interventions to improve either oxygen saturation and/or delivery, transfusion of red blood cells is commonly employed in the cardiac ICU. Scarce data on the optimal transfusion thresholds following cardiac surgery (and in the setting of univentricular physiology) are available. The known risks/complications associated with red blood cell transfusion include transfusion-associated lung injury, immune modulation/inflammatory response, infection risk (rare), and transfusion reaction (probably underestimated). In the setting of left-to-right shunt physiology, increasing hematocrit is known to be associated with increased PVR and improved oxygen delivery.25 Accordingly, maintenance of oxygen-carrying capacity by attaining a goal hemoglobin of >13 mg/dL has been an unspoken tenet in the cardiac ICU, particularly in the care of those with univentricular physiology. However, recent studies have raised doubts about the liberal use of transfusion. Salvin and colleagues demonstrated longer duration of mechanical ventilation, higher incidence of infection, and acute kidney injury in the high transfusion exposure group (>15 mL/kg) when compared with the low (<15 mL/kg) or nontransfusion groups in the first 48 postoperative hours.26 Both transfusion groups were associated with increased length of stay in patients undergoing biventricular repairs but not those undergoing univentricular palliation. Blackwood and colleagues retrospectively analyzed the impact of transfusion on outcome in patients with HLHS. Greater transfusion in the immediate postoperative period was associated with increased duration of ventilation. Interestingly, hemoglobin level and transfusion were not associated with 2-year mortality or neurodevelopmental outcomes.27 While the limitations of these studies are numerous, they underscore the importance of continued study in this area and suggest a more judicious approach to transfusion may be appropriate.

sec.title: Nutrition
sec.p: Poor growth in infants with HLHS is associated with significant morbidity and has proven difficult to modify. No single feeding strategy has emerged as best practice to improve weight gain. Patients with complex CHD are known to have congenital feeding difficulties28 as well as being at high risk of developing gastrointestinal morbidities.29 Of particular concern, CHD has been found to be a predisposing factor for the development of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in near-term and term neonates.30 The incidence of NEC among infants with CHD is far greater than that of the general population with those born at earlier gestational age, receiving high-dose prostaglandin therapy and those with an occurrence of shock or low cardiac output being at highest risk.31 Of the anatomic subtypes, infants with univentricular anatomy appear to be among those most at risk.31 The NEC-associated morbidity and mortality remains elevated following the Norwood procedure.29 Mesenteric perfusion is thought to be at risk due to diastolic runoff via a large patent ductus arteriosus or BTS,32 thus underscoring the importance of maintaining a balanced circulation that will provide adequate Qs and oxygen delivery to the splanchnic circulation. The lack of diastolic runoff was touted as a significant benefit for the RV-PA conduit as part of the initial surgical palliation of the univentricular heart. However, del Castillo and colleagues33 recently showed that postprandial mesenteric blood flow velocities were lower among patients with an RV-PA conduit, suggesting these patients may still be at risk of NEC. In the postoperative patient, there is continued hesitance to initiate feedings and/or aggressively advance them due to the same concerns. Braudis and colleagues demonstrated that the use of an enteral feeding algorithm in patients with postoperative HLHS was safe and resulted in faster achievement of optimal caloric intake with no incidence of NEC.34 While initially thought to be only an immediate postoperative problem, it appears that this may have implications for the “interstage” period35 and bidirectional Glenn operation.36 Given these findings, renewed efforts to understand and optimize nutrition in this at-risk cohort is warranted.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: While management of patients with univentricular physiology remains challenging, advances in prenatal diagnosis and pre- and postoperative management have significantly improved survival in this population. There remains significant room for improvement. Future studies should focus on optimizing and standardizing in-hospital and out-of-hospital care with improving morbidity, mortality, and functional outcomes.

fn.p: Presented at the Third Scientific Meeting of the World Society for Pediatric and Congenital Heart Surgery, Istanbul, Turkey; June 23–26, 2011.
